utterances: I don't quite understand what the commercial model is.
How are you actually making money from it?
Some of the other presenters, a solar-powered DJ and a guy with a line of eco-friendly products that devotes a percentage of profits to the developing world.
And I'm being told that we've got a winner of - what were we giving away again?
(Unintelligible)
Oh, a (unintelligible).
Right, just to make it interesting.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Solomon Rothman, ladies and gentlemen.
(Soundbite of cheering and applause)
Rothman's idea is something called open source filmmaking.
It lets people collaborate on a movie, even change the final product and then show it on the Web.
It's not set up like Wikipedia where everyone can contribute equal amounts.
You still have to have some type of tools to make films and people work together on what they can.
And yes, there is opportunity for people to retake that work and make their own versions, just like in open source software.
And after interviewing Rothman and hearing his pitch, I'm still not sure how this film thing works or makes any money.
But he comes to Bloblive every single week and he says it's definitely improved his presentation skills.
Another entrepreneur, Chris Easter, says the connections he made at Bloblive gave a boost to a business he and two partners had already started, a Web site for bridegrooms called The Man Registry.
We've gotten PR out of it.
We've gotten interest in financing out of it.
You can't put a price tag on what goes on here.
Even the people who just came to watch had ideas, plans or products.
Vicky Kisella invented these lacy mini-socks that peeked out around the edge of her shoes.
Aren't they darling?
They're fashionable and they are functional.
But Kisella didn't have the nerve to get on stage.
Whether I present it or not, it was about getting inspired and being with like-minded people.
Another onlooker inspired by Bloblive was TV producer Garry Grossman.
We think there may be a TV show in this.
It's a great thing to see people with ideas up on stage, trying to explain why they may have the million-dollar idea or an idea that could help a million people.
So whatever happens to the individual presenters here, Bloblive itself could be the next big thing.
(Soundbite of song, ""Beware of the Blob"")
(Singing) Beware of the Blob.
It creeps and leaps and glides and slides across the floor…
Ina Jaffe, NPR News.
(Singing) …right through the door and all around the wall.
A splotch, a blotch, be careful of the Blob.
Capitol Hill was quieter today.
One day after the stunning rejection of the bailout, there may be another vote later this week.
But today, everyone could agree on one thing, the first vote failed for lack of leadership on all sides.
And joining us to talk about what went wrong is NPR's national political correspondent Mara Liasson.
Hey, Mara.
Hello, Melissa.
And let's start first with President Bush.
He has been out there urging both parties to approve this deal.
He made a brief statement this morning, again warning of dire consequences if a bill isn't passed.
Let's listen.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: We're facing a choice between action and the real prospect of economic hardship for millions of Americans.
Mara, is anybody in Washington taking cues from this lame duck president?
Well, it sure doesn't seem to.
They certainly didn't take cues from his speech last week.
He is a true lame duck.
In the latest Washington Post-ABC poll, he had a 70 percent disapproval rating.
He seems to be out of juice with his own party.
There are 19 Republicans in the House from Texas and only three of them voted for this bill.
So at this point, it's not for nothing that Newsweek has named Henry Paulson as the king of Washington.
He seems to represent the administration now, and he also failed, because he put forward a tone deaf initial version of that plan that was off-putting, to put it mildly.
What about the House leadership here, Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Minority Leader John Boehner?
But in October, U.S.
District Judge Reed O'Connor struck down the Indian Child Welfare Act as unconstitutional.
The Texas judge ruled the law is a racially based preference that discriminates against non-Indian families.
The problem was that it was so poorly worded that it now inflicts harms on Indian children that it was supposed to protect.
Thank you, Alex.
Iowa is very important, and with some candidates it could make or break them - Huckabee and also John Edwards.
If they don't win, some things could be pretty bad for them in the near future.
Also, it shows momentum.
It's also a litmus test for message and organizing, so I think for certain candidates, it's really big.
We just heard from Mara Liasson talking a bit about the structure of the caucuses, the weather, things like that.

Jamal, when you look at this particular caucus where you do have a host of Republicans and a host of Democrats, not just one party, you have a president who will be leaving office, a two-term president, what's the general mood and what's the energy level?
On the Democratic side, the energy level seems to be very high.
Most Democrats are looking for somebody who's going to really offer change and really bring the country to a different place.

And right now, what we're hearing from a lot of people is that Republican and independents are really -many independents and some Republicans are really looking at the Democrats as maybe their option this year to go and caucus for.
There's a lot of energy in the Democratic side right now.
And, you know what?
I agree with Jamal dealing with the independents, but not just looking at Democrats.
I think, Jamal, you have some independents that are out there looking at Republicans as well.
We are…
That's a much smaller percentage.
I'm sorry.
Go ahead, Jamal.
I'm sorry.
It's a much smaller percentage that are headed toward the Republican side.
Let me jump in here for a second, because I'm wondering if either of you is troubled by the idea of walkup registration and that possibly skewing the vote.
I'm going to go with you first, Angela, and then Jamal, give me your read…
Well, you know…
…I mean, in terms of party affiliation.
…it's their process and I had a conversation with many Iowans and they take this very seriously and some people are making up their minds last minute.
I think it's great.
I think sometimes when we do party politics, just as 90 percent of black folks, vote a straight Democrat ticket, but you saw in 2004, Bush won because he had 16 percent of the black vote in Ohio.
So I like the fact that people can go up and register and you might be a Democrat, you might see a Republican that you like, and you can go out and register as a Republican.
So I like the process.
Jamal.
I agree with Angela on this.
Politics is a game of addition.
We shouldn't be in the business of keeping people out of voting for candidates.
And in fact, for a Democrat to win, they've got to win a fair number of independents and Republicans in order to carry the day in the fall.
And Jamal is right.
It is not going to be Democrats or Republicans, I believe, that's going to make the selection.
If you have a Hillary and Giuliani, they're going to go after that independent vote, that swing vote.
And I think that's it's really important.
Sometimes, party politics can be partisan politics.
Let me tell you a little bit about what we did yesterday.
We had two black Iowan voters on the show, different parties talking about some of the challenges in African-American communities.
I want to play just a little bit for you.
Even though we represent about 2.5 percent of the entire state population, we represent about 26, 27 percent of those in the prison population in the state of Iowa.
And in order to address those kinds of issues, we have to look obviously at education, what's going on there, where are the breakdown.
We believe the increased expulsions and suspensions are closely related to the problems associated with the other criminal justice issues.
